awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Advanced Mycotoxin Detection with Novel Photochemical Diagnostics
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is improved sustainable food production. Mycotoxins are common contaminants found in cereal grains that can track through feed production and ultimately poison livestock animals. These poisoning events manifest as waste and inefficiency within human food supply chains. Animals consuming contaminated feed grow more slowly, produce less milk/eggs, are more susceptible to disease, etc. This equates to lost profits for the famers, lost meals for the consumer, and concerns over long-term food security. This SBIR Phase I project addresses this challenge through detection of these toxins. This technique offers a potentially transformative new tool in the field of point-of-source diagnostics, while simultaneously addressing the needs of the industry. This toxin detection system will be faster, simpler, and more versatile.

The proposed project advances a new generation of mycotoxin detection technologies. This technique employs novel compounds designed to associate with a specific mycotoxin of interest to enable reliable quantitative detection. These detector compounds operate by changing the spectroscopic properties of the toxin, such that it can be detected even in complex biological mixtures like animal feed. The project investigates the extraction buffer composition and the detector compound design. The buffer and detector compound combinations will be optimized by characterizing the spectroscopic signatures under different excitation conditions.  This research program will target the two key classes of mycotoxins most relevant to industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
ExciPlex received the NSF Phase I SBIR award 2127018 in December 2021 for the development of novel mycotoxin detection technologies. The primary focus was to prove feasible the application of ExciPlex’s photochemical detection technique for the identification and quantification of mycotoxins in feed and feed ingredient samples. As a result of Phase I efforts, ExciPlex has achieved proof-of-concept for the four most relevant mycotoxins to the grain and livestock industries, a crucial step en route to developing first-in-class on-farm mycotoxin detection technologies.

      Mycotoxins are small molecule toxins produced by fungal pathogens common in cereal grain production. These toxins can persist through grain harvesting and processing, thus detection and remediation are necessary to avoid contamination of downstream feed and food products. Existing detection methods are employed at grain-receiving stages, but survey data of finished animal feeds has demonstrated that this single quality control checkpoint is insufficient. Farm-made feeds, such as silages and haylages, are of particularly high concern given that these feeds bypass commercial grain mills. Contaminated animal feed leads to lower productivity and thus lower profitability for livestock and aquaculture producers. The reduced productivity necessarily equates to increased resource inputs per pound of edible protein. Raising livestock animals requires water, fertilizer, energy, pesticides, etc. for their food, shelter, healthcare, etc., and the total sum of each resource is increased by a mycotoxin-based multiplier due to incomplete quality control frameworks. Fortunately, mycotoxin remediation products are commercially-available and are an active area of research in the industry. Feed producers and farmers can eliminate concerns over mycotoxin poisoning risks if the contamination is identified and quantified appropriately (and in a timely manner). ExciPlex’s technology was designed to provide the versatility needed to test for these toxins across the myriad feed types and various settings in order to enable the more proactive paradigm that is necessary for optimal protein production efficiency and sustainability.

      The Phase I research efforts were dedicated to the development of ExciPlex’s diagnostic science. Rooted in state-of-the-art photochemistry, ExciPlex’s technique creates measurable signals through the use of “detector compounds” which selectively associate with the toxins of interest. This association manipulates the properties of the toxin such that it can be detected with standard spectroscopic techniques. Achieving commercially-relevant toxin detection requires that the assay: 1) distinguishes between various toxins, 2) generates signal at low levels of toxin contamination, and 3) performs consistently across all feed types (from raw corn to corn silage).

      The Phase I efforts achieved several key milestones en route to a commercial-ready mycotoxin detection assay. Aqueous buffer systems were designed and optimized to extract mycotoxins from various feed types and provide the foundation for uniform spectroscopic performance. Lead detector compounds were identified for each of the top tier mycotoxins targeted in the Phase I research plan. Selected assay formulations (extraction buffer + detector compound) were shown to yield coherent trends between toxin concentration and signal production, and these trends could be used to quantify the concentration in other samples, even approaching the targeted lowest level of quantification. The combined outcomes of the Phase I research were in line with projections and have assuredly positioned ExciPlex for success in subsequent development efforts.

      Based on the advances achieved in Phase I, ExciPlex will continue to develop its mycotoxin detection technologies to field-ready levels. Remaining focus areas include further bolstering signal production through detector compound refinement as well as improving accuracy and precision through more advanced background subtraction algorithms. ExciPlex is committed to providing the next generation of mycotoxin detection technologies and ameliorating the mycotoxin burden on grain, feed, livestock, and aquaculture industries.

 


Last Modified: 05/31/2023
Modified by: Daryl Staveness
